page.title: 13GREAT BUDWORTH, CHESHIRE.
page.content: Great Budworth is a picturesque village two miles to the north of Northwich. It is situated on a hilltop and its fourteenth century church is a prominent local landmark. The largest parish in Cheshire used to be centred on the church, comprising 35 townships which explains why Budworth has the prefix Great. The church contains a massive medieval oak chest which has four locks. It is tradition for the keys to be held by four separate people, three churchwardens and the vicar. There has been a school in Great Budworth since 1600, when a Grammar School was founded. When it moved to Northwich, the building became the village school and remained in use until 1857 when the present school was built. Many village schools are under threat of closure, but Great Budworth school should survive.
